features.text: ### Hydropower uses the energy of moving waters and is one of the oldest sources of renewable energy

features.text: Hydropower uses water from rivers or stored in dams to produce electricity through the rotation of turbine blades To plan the production or storage of water and evaluate the impact on the energy market, it is necessary to quantify not only the rain, but also the water contained within the snowpack This is known as the Snow Water Equivalent (SWE)
features.title: text 1
features.__generatedText__:
Hydropower uses water from rivers or stored in dams to produce electricity through the rotation of turbine blades

To plan the production or storage of water and evaluate the impact on the energy market, it is necessary to quantify not only the rain, but also the water contained within the snowpack

This is known as the Snow Water Equivalent (SWE)

features.text:
To make the renewable power production more efficient it is necessary to have accurate measurements of snow water equivalent and snow cover


These measurements allow to predict the inflow at the turbine


A better evaluation of the water stored in the snow could improve the forecast of hydroelectric energy production with positive effects on the business management The quantification of the snow water equivalent (SWE) accumulated upstream a production plant is a recurrent activity that is performed by hydropower companies to monitor the energy potential stored in the snow

features.text: Earth Observation (EO) is a great source of information to quantify the area covered by snow in a basin The current bottleneck is given by the ambiguity between snow and clouds that, in the optical images, share the same reflectance response To improve the revisit frequency of the snow cover product, the EO4Alps project is taking advantage of high-resolution binary snow cover maps from Sentinel-2, SAR data from Sentinel-1 and coarser resolution daily optical images, e.g. Sentinel-3 By combining the latest technology in snow modelling and EO it is possible to provide an estimate of Snow Water Equivalent (SWE) in quasi-real time at Alpine scale
features.title: text 3
features.__generatedText__:
Earth Observation (EO) is a great source of information to quantify the area covered by snow in a basin

The current bottleneck is given by the ambiguity between snow and clouds that, in the optical images, share the same reflectance response

To improve the revisit frequency of the snow cover product, the EO4Alps project is taking advantage of high-resolution binary snow cover maps from Sentinel-2, SAR data from Sentinel-1 and coarser resolution daily optical images, e.g. Sentinel-3

By combining the latest technology in snow modelling and EO it is possible to provide an estimate of Snow Water Equivalent (SWE) in quasi-real time at Alpine scale

features.text: Austria’s alpine topography, together with the numerous rivers and high precipitation, provide the country with significant water resources Hydropower today accounts for more than half of total installed power generating capacity. More than 3,000 hydropower stations are connected to the national grid, with a further 2,000 very small projects used for on-site consumption off the grid (International Hydropower Association). With an estimated technical and economic potential of 56.1 TWh, Austria has exploited some 75 per cent of its potential.

features.__generatedText__:
Austria’s alpine topography, together with the numerous rivers and high precipitation, provide the country with significant water resources

Hydropower today accounts for more than half of total installed power generating capacity.

More than 3,000 hydropower stations are connected to the national grid, with a further 2,000 very small projects used for on-site consumption off the grid (International Hydropower Association).

With an estimated technical and economic potential of 56.1 TWh, Austria has exploited some 75 per cent of its potential.

features.text:
According to a 2008 Pöyry study, the remaining economically and environmentally feasible potential totals 12.8 TWh

According to the Austrian Electricity Strategy, Empowering Austria, 6 to 8 TWh could be developed up to 2030 (International Hydropower Association)

In this particular scenario within the GTIF demonstrator, the objective is to showcase how EO and geospatial analysis can provide actional information on SWE for hydro power management improvement, in support of the renewable energy transition in Austria
